Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Research Experiences in Physiology and Neurobioloby at UCONN
Award.AbstractNarration: A Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) Sites award has been made to the University of Connecticut to provide research training for 10 weeks for 10 students during the summers of 2013-1015. The Department of Physiology and Neurobiology (PNB) will offer research opportunities to undergraduate sophomores and juniors from non-Ph.D. granting institutions. The students will participate in graduate level research projects on physiological and neural systems in animals. The goal is to expose students to a career in scientific research, and to increase student applications to graduate programs in basic science. Students are selected on the basis of their academic record, personal and professional goals described in a required essay, and letters of recommendation. Interested students, especially underrepresented minorities, veterans, first-generation college students, and students with disabilities from institutions with limited research opportunities are encouraged to apply. REU students will be part of a campus multidisciplinary REU community consisting of several programs in the physical sciences and engineering as well as physiology and neurobiology. Students are housed together, and work with faculty mentors on their own research project. Professional development and cohort-building activities are planned. Seminars introduce students to topics such as safe practices in the laboratories, ethical issues in science, how to apply to graduate school, and how to present research results effectively. An end-of-session symposium features student platform and poster presentations. Information about the program will be assessed by various means, including the common assessment tool available to BIO-funded REU PIs. More information is available by visiting http://www.pnb.uconn.edu/PNB_Base/reu/index.html, or by contacting the PI (Dr. Xinnian Chen at xinnian.chen@uconn.edu) or the co-PI (Dr. Larry Renfro at larry.renfro@uconn.edu)

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit:

Overall, the goals of our program were met. The major objective was to provide undergraduates from diverse and primarily non-Ph.D. granting institutions an opportunity to immerse themselves in the collegial atmosphere of stimulating research laboratories and to promote in each an interest in a career in the sciences.  Over the past nine summers we brought a total of 89 students through the program.  

The following table summarizes our results for applications. Since our last grant cycle, we increased our goals for recruitment to 20% applications and 50% participants representing targeted groups.

*: Target Schools: Non-PhD Granting institutions

**: in 2007, 2010, and 2013 application process began late due to delay in notification of funding

As the table below shows, we met our goal of at least 50% of REU participants from targeted populations.  40% were URM students and almost 100% were from non-PhD granting institutions.  In addition, at least 30% overall were first generation college students.   In addition, we accommodated two students with disabilities (one with traumatic brain injury and a second with post-spinal cord injury lower extremity paresis.)  

*One student left the program during the sixth week due to family issues

** identified as Black/Native American

***Roster for 2011 included one non-traditional (adult) student, two for 2012, and one for 2013

REU Seminars were integral to our program. In this grant cycle, we have added 5-5 mentoring lunch meetings to foster mentor-mentee relationship. The final Poster Symposium has been an important culminating event.  

Overall, post-program surveys and interviews, follow-up emails strongly indicate that students gain an appreciation for and understanding of the life of a research scientist as a result of the PNB REU program.  A majority of those who continue on to become PhD students express the conviction that our program was instrumental in their decision to attend graduate school.  

To this date, our REU site has produced six peer-reviewed journal articles. 

Broader Impact:

            Over the 9 years, 89 students with limited research opportunities, underrepresented minority students, students with disabilities, and veterans were able to be exposed to life in the research lab, where they learn how to pose research questions, work as part of a research team, learn cutting-edge techniques, and experience the first hand opportunity to devise their own research questions and the means to answer them. Many previous REU students reported "a great deal of ownership over my REU project". Some have reported learning their true passion about research. REU participants grew in skills, gained confidence, developed a sense of belonging in the science community, and established networks with peers from a range of disciplines and experiences. The program opens the possibility of a scientific research career to students who may otherwise not have the opportunity to explore such an option first-hand. We have obtain updates on 85 of the 89 (note: two participated twice) students who completed the program from 2007-2015:  53/89 (60%) matriculated in (or graduated from) graduate or professional school; 28/89 (31%) in PhD programs in NSF-related fields; 10 report plans to apply to graduate school. Many current PhD students spontaneously cited this program as instrumental in their decision to attend and success in graduate school.  Furthermore, their participation in social and educational activities with an ethnically diverse group of summer research students has better prepared them to work in a multicultural world.
